content:
No, a positive association between having a high income and going on expensive vacations does not necessarily mean that having a high income tends to lead to going on expensive vacations.

Correlation does not imply causality, meaning that just because two variables are related does not necessarily mean that one causes the other. There are many other explanations for why two variables might be related, such as a common underlying cause, reverse causality, or the presence of confounding variables.

In this case, it is possible that the relationship is due to a third variable (such as education, occupation, or inherited wealth) that affects both the exposure (high income) and the outcome (expensive vacations). This third variable could be the real cause of the observed relationship, rather than high income leading to expensive vacations.

It's also possible that the observed relationship could be due to reverse causality, where going on expensive vacations leads to having a high income, rather than the other way around.

Therefore, simply observing a positive association between having a high income and going on expensive vacations does not necessarily mean that having a high income causes expensive vacations, or that going on expensive vacations causes a high income. To determine causality, more rigorous research methods such as a randomized controlled trial or a longitudinal study would be needed.
